abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Network Improvement
            Project for Vietnam were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: expectations of project
            outcomes need to be tempered with realistic assessments of
            what can be achieved within a single intervention.
            Introducing new systems, such as a road asset management
            system, requires a major program of change within a road
            agency. Where these changes span new technical systems,
            functional roles and responsibilities, and multiple
            stakeholder agencies there is a need to ensure that such
            reforms are introduced at a pace that they can be absorbed
            and accepted. Fundamental aspect of a functioning road
            management system is having both the technical capacity and
            financial resources to ensure regular and reliable data
            collection for monitoring and evaluating performance.
            Long-term strategic planning provides an important platform
            for communicating a sectoral vision to stakeholders. Going
            forward, the Ministry of Transport can build on this
            approach by updating the ten year strategy for road
            maintenance to address future institutional and policy
            goals, defining the role of small and medium enterprises in
            the maintenance sector, and setting and measuring network
            performance targets and fiscal projections, all of which can
            contribute to better sector governance and facilitate donor
            engagement. Capacity development for land acquisition and
            resettlement remain paramount for improving implementation
            performance. Both Vietnam and the Bank must intensify their
            efforts to refining country systems for land acquisition and
            resettlement. The Bank task team should also be proactive in
            advising relevant government officials on appropriate
            solutions to meeting Bank safeguard requirements,
            particularly where complex local conditions make policy
            compliance difficult to achieve. The existing project
            management unit structure misses opportunities to mainstream
            roles and responsibilities into relevant Ministerial
            departments. Various governance challenges exist within this
            organizational structure and may actually present an
            obstacle to improving public sector performance in
            infrastructure service delivery.
